sense.def: the first letter of the alpha- bet, followed by B

cit.quote: an enormous hole
a useful guidebook

sense.note: NOTE: an is used before words beginning with a, e, i, o, u and with h if the h is not pronounced: an apple or an hour. a is used before words begin- ning with all other letters and also be- fore u where u is pronounced /ju / : a useful guidebook)

sense.def: for each or to each

cit.quote: Apples cost £1.50 a kilo

sense.def: to leave someone or something in an unkind way

sense.def: to give up or stop doing some- thing

sense.def: a short form of a word

sense.def: the fact of being clever

sense.def: good at doing something, or good at doing many things

sense.def: referring to something

sense.def: not exactly

while you're about it at the same time as the thing you are doing ć While you're about it, can you post this letter

sense.def: to say 'yes' or to agree to something

sense.def: to go with someone or something

take something into account to consider something ć We have to take the weather into account
on no ac- count not at all

entry.re: 2. to put a question to get someone to do something ć Ask your father to teach you how to drive. ć Can I ask you not to make so much noise? 3. to invite someone to an event or to do something ć We asked them to our party. ć She asked me to go skiing with her

entry.re: for having done something wrong ć I'm not going to take the blame for something I didn't do. ˽ to get the blame for something to be accused of something ć Who got the blame for breaking the window? -Me, of course! ˽ to take the blame for something to accept that you were re- sponsible for something bad í verb ˽ to blame someone for something, to blame something on someone to say that someone is responsible for some- thing ć Blame my sister for the awful food, not me. ć He blamed the accident on the bad weather. ˽ I don't blame you I think you're right to do that ć I don't blame you for being annoyed, when everyone else got a present and you didn't. ˽ you have only yourself to blame no one else is responsible for what happened ć You have only yourself to blame if you missed the chance of a free ticket. ˽ to be to blame for to be re- sponsible for something ć The manager is to blame for the bad service

sense.re: to compete with someone or something to try to be more successful than some- one or something in an activity, espe- cially in business ć We have to compete with a range of cheap imports

sense.def: the quality of being able to do a job or task well enough

cit.quote: Does she have the necessary competence in foreign lan- guages?

sense.def: the quality of being legally suitable or qualified to do something

cit.quote: The case falls within the competence of the tribunal
This is outside the com- petence of this court

sense.def: efficient

cit.quote: She is a very competent man- ager

sense.def: legally or officially able to do something

cit.quote: The organisation is not competent to deal with this case

sense.def: an event in which several teams or peo- ple compete with each other

cit.quote: France were the winners of the competition
He won first prize in the piano competi- tion

sense.note: NOTE: The plural in this sense is competitions

sense.def: a situation in busi- ness in which one person or company is trying to do better than another

cit.quote: Our main competition comes from the big supermarkets

sense.def: people or companies who are trying to do better than you

cit.quote: We have lowered our prices to try to beat the competition
The competition is or are planning to reduce their prices

sense.note: NOTE: singular in this sense, but can take a plural verb

sense.def: liking to win competitions

cit.quote: He's very competitive

sense.def: having a business advan- tage, especially by being cheaper

cit.quote: competitive prices
We must reduce costs to remain competitive

sense.def: a per- son who enters a competition

cit.quote: All the competitors lined up for the start of the race

sense.def: a company which competes with another in the same business

cit.quote: Two German firms are our main competi- tors

sense.def: to say that something is not good or does not work properly

cit.quote: The shop is so cold the staff have started complaining
They are complaining that our prices are too high

sense.note: NOTE: You complain to someone about something or that something is not good enough.

sense.def: an oc- casion when someone says that some- thing is not good enough or does not work properly

cit.quote: She sent her letter of complaint to the directors
You must file your complaint with the relevant de- partment

sense.def: an illness

cit.quote: She was admit- ted to hospital with a kidney complaint

sense.def: with all its parts

cit.quote: He has a complete set of the new stamps

sense.def: finished

cit.quote: The build- ing is nearly complete

sense.note: NOTE: used af- ter a verb

sense.def: used for emphasis

cit.quote: The trip was a complete waste of money

sense.def: to finish something

cit.quote: The build- ers completed the whole job in two days

sense.def: to fill in a form

cit.quote: When you have completed the application form, send it to us in the envelope provided

sense.def: totally

cit.quote: The town was completely destroyed in the earthquake
I completely forgot about my dentist's appointment

sense.def: compli- cated

cit.quote: This really is a complex prob- lem

sense.def: a group of buildings

cit.quote: The council has built a new sports com- plex

sense.def: a worry or an unreasonable fear

cit.quote: He has a complex about going bald

sense.def: difficult to understand, with many small details

cit.quote: It is a complicated subject
It's all getting too complicated -let's try and keep it simple
Chess has quite complicated rules
The route to get to our house is rather complicated, so I'll draw you a map

sense.def: something that causes difficulties
an illness occurring because of or dur- ing another illness

cit.quote: She appeared to be getting better, but complications set in

sense.def: a nice thing that you say to someone about their appearance or about some- thing good they have done

cit.quote: I've had so many compliments about my new hair- style today

sense.def: to praise someone or tell them how nice they look

cit.quote: I would like to compliment the chef on an excellent meal
She complimented me on my work

sense.note: NOTE: Do not confuse with complement

sense.def: a small part of something larger, especial- ly a small piece of a machine

cit.quote: a manu- facturer of computer components
Each section of the plan is broken down into separate components

sense.def: forming part of something larger
to write something, thinking carefully about it

cit.quote: He sat down to compose a letter to his family
It took Mozart only three days to compose his fifth piano concerto

sense.def: something which has been composed, e.g. a poem or piece of music

cit.quote: We will now play a well-known composition by Dowland

sense.def: an essay or piece of writing on a special subject

cit.quote: We had three hours to write a composition on 'pollu- tion'

sense.def: made up of several parts

cit.quote: The word 'address book' is a compound noun

sense.def: a chemical made up of two or more elements

cit.quote: Water is a compound of two gases, oxygen and hydrogen

sense.def: buildings and land enclosed by a fence

cit.quote: Soldiers were guarding the prison compound
Guard dogs patrol the compound at night

sense.def: essential, or required by a rule or law

cit.quote: a compulsory charge for admission
It is compulsory to complete all pages of the form

sense.def: an elec- tronic machine which processes and keeps information automatically, and which can be used for connecting to the Internet and sending emails
sense.re: on com- puter kept in a computer ć All our com- pany records are on computer

sense.def: the use of computers
to hide some- thing or put it where it cannot be seen

cit.quote: He tried to conceal the camera by putting it under his coat

sense.def: to prevent someone from discovering some infor- mation

cit.quote: He concealed the fact that he had a brother in prison

sense.def: think- ing that you are better, more intelligent, or more talented than other people

cit.quote: He's the most conceited and selfish per- son I've ever known

sense.def: to give your careful attention to something

cit.quote: The exam candidates were all concen- trating on their questions when the elec- tricity went off

sense.def: the act of thinking carefully about something

cit.quote: A loud conversation in the next room disturbed my concen- tration
His concentration slipped and he lost the next two games

sense.def: a lot of things together in one area

cit.quote: the con- centration of computer companies in the south of Scotland
The concentration of wild animals round the water hole makes it easy for lions to catch their prey

sense.def: an idea about something or about how something works

cit.quote: I'll quickly explain the basic concepts of safe working in this environ- ment
The concept of punctuation and grammar is completely foreign to her
Our children have absolutely no con- cept of tidiness

sense.def: to have a particular thing as a subject

cit.quote: The film concerns children growing up in the 1950s

sense.re: to concern yourself with something to deal with something ć You needn't concern yourself with cleaning the shop

sense.def: to make someone worry

cit.quote: It concerns me that he is always late for work

sense.def: worry

cit.quote: She's a cause of great concern to her family

sense.def: interest

cit.quote: My main concern is to en- sure that we all enjoy ourselves
The teachers showed no concern at all for the children's safety

sense.def: a company or business

cit.quote: a big German chemical con- cern

sense.def: worried

cit.quote: She looked concerned
I could tell something was wrong by the concerned look on her face
We are concerned about her behaviour -do you think she is having problems at school?

sense.def: involved in or affected by something

cit.quote: I'll speak to the parents concerned

sense.def: showing interest in some- thing

cit.quote: I'm concerned to know what people thought after the information session

sense.def: about; on the subject of

cit.quote: He filled in a questionnaire concerning hol- idays
I'd like to speak to Mr Robin- son concerning his application for in- surance
Anyone with information concerning this person should get in touch with the police

sense.def: an occasion on which music is played in public

cit.quote: I couldn't go to the concert, so I gave my ticket to a friend

sense.def: to end; to come to an end

cit.quote: He concluded by thanking all those who had helped ar- range the exhibition
The concert con- cluded with a piece by Mozart

sense.def: to come to an opinion from the informa- tion available

cit.quote: The police concluded that the thief had got into the building through the broken kitchen window

sense.def: the end of something

cit.quote: At the conclusion of the trial all the accused were found guilty

sense.def: an opinion which you reach af- ter thinking carefully

cit.quote: She came to or reached the conclusion that he had found another girlfriend
What con- clusions can you draw from the evi- dence

sense.def: a mixture of a grey powder called cement, and sand, used in building

cit.quote: Concrete was invent- ed by the Romans
The pavement is made of slabs of concrete

sense.def: made of concrete

cit.quote: a concrete path

sense.def: firm or definite, rather than vague

cit.quote: The police are sure he is guilty, but they have no concrete evidence against him
I need to see some concrete proposals very soon

sense.def: referring to something with a physical structure

cit.quote: A stone is a concrete object

sense.def: to say strongly that you do not approve of something

cit.quote: She condemned the police for their treatment of the prisoners

sense.def: to sentence a criminal

cit.quote: She was con- demned to death

sense.def: a state that something or someone is in

cit.quote: The car is in very good condition
He was taken to hospital when his condition got worse

sense.def: something which has to be agreed before something else is done

cit.quote: They didn't agree with some of the con- ditions of the contract
One of condi- tions of the deal is that the company pays all travel costs

entry.re: on condition that only if ć I will come on condition that you pay my fare

sense.def: a way of be- having

cit.quote: His conduct in class is becom- ing worse
Her conduct during the tri- al was remarkably calm

sense.def: to do something in an organised or particular way

cit.quote: I don't like the way they conduct their affairs
They are con- ducting an experiment into the effect of TV advertising

sense.re: to conduct yourself to behave in a particular way ć I was im- pressed by the calm way in which she conducted herself. ć The children con- ducted themselves well during the long speeches

sense.def: to direct or take someone to a place

cit.quote: The guests were conducted to their seats

sense.def: to direct the way in which a musician or singer performs

cit.quote: The or- chestra was conducted by a Russian conductor

sense.def: to allow electricity or heat to pass through

cit.quote: Copper conducts electricity very well

sense.def: the per- son who sells tickets on a bus
the per- son who directs the way an orchestra plays
a metal or other substance through which electricity or heat can pass

cit.quote: Copper is a good conductor but plastic is not

sense.def: a shape which is round at the base, rising to a point above

cit.quote: He rolled the newspaper to form a cone

sense.def: to discuss

cit.quote: The leader of the Council conferred with the Town Clerk

sense.def: to give something such as a responsibility, legal right or honour to someone

cit.quote: the powers con- ferred on the council by law

sense.def: a large meeting where people who are in- terested in the same thing come together

cit.quote: The organisation holds an annual conference in Brighton

sense.def: a meeting of a group or society

cit.quote: The annual confer- ence of the Electricians' Union
2000 people attended the conference on ge- netic engineering

sense.def: to admit that you have committed a crime or done some- thing wrong

cit.quote: He confessed to six bur- glaries
She confessed that she had forgotten to lock the door

sense.def: a state- ment in which someone admits they have committed a crime or done some- thing wrong

cit.quote: The prisoner said his confession had been forced from him by the police
I was surprised by her con- fession of ignorance about the correct procedures to follow
I have a confes- sion to make -I forgot to send the cheque

sense.def: a feeling of being sure about your own or someone else's abilities

cit.quote: The staff do not have much confidence in their man- ager
I have total confidence in the pi- lot
He hasn't got much confidence in himself

sense.def: the fact of being secret

entry.re: in confidence as a secret ć He showed me the report in confidence

sense.def: sure that you or something will be successful

cit.quote: I am confident (that) the show will go off well
She's confident of doing well in the exam

sense.def: secret or private

cit.quote: This information is strictly confidential

sense.def: in a way which shows that you are confident

cit.quote: She walked confidently into the inter- view room

sense.def: to say that something is certain

cit.quote: The dates of the concerts have been confirmed by the pop group's manager
The photo- graph confirmed that the result of the race was a dead heat
We have been told that she left the country last month -can you confirm that

sense.def: a strong disagreement or argument
fighting

cit.quote: The government is engaged in armed conflict with rebel forces

sense.re: to come into conflict with someone to start to disagree strongly with someone ć They soon came into conflict over who should be in charge

sense.def: to disagree with someone or something

cit.quote: His ver- sion of events conflicts with that of his partner

sense.def: to make someone feel that they cannot under- stand something

cit.quote: She was confused by all the journalists' questions

sense.def: to mix things or people up

cit.quote: The twins are so alike I am always confusing them
I always confuse him with his brother - they are very alike

sense.def: unable to understand or to think clearly

cit.quote: I'm a bit confused -did we say 8 p.m. or 8.30?
Grandmother used to get rather con- fused in her old age

sense.def: diffi- cult to understand

cit.quote: They found the in- structions on the computer very confus- ing

sense.def: a state of not knowing what to do or how to decide something

cit.quote: Her reply just created more confusion over who was responsible

sense.def: in confusion not able to decide what is happening or what to do

cit.quote: He was looking at the letter in great confusion

sense.def: a state in which things are not organised in the correct way or are not clear

cit.quote: There were scenes of confu- sion at the airport when the snow stopped all flights

sense.def: to tell someone that you are very pleased that they have been successful

cit.quote: I want to congratulate you on your pro- motion

sense.def: to give someone your best wishes on a special occasion

cit.quote: He con- gratulated them on their silver wedding anniversary

sense.note: NOTE: You congratulate someone on something

sense.def: praise for someone who has done well

cit.quote: His grandparents sent him a let- ter of congratulation on passing his de- gree

sense.def: congratulations an expression of good wishes to some- one who has done well or who is cele- brating a special occasion

cit.quote: a congrat- ulations card
Congratulations - you're our millionth customer!
Con- gratulations on passing your exam!
The office sent him their congratula- tions on his wedding

sense.def: a word which connects different sections of a sentence. 'and' and 'but' are con- junctions

sense.re: in conjunction with someone or something together with someone or something ć The icy road in conjunction with fog made driving very difficult

sense.def: to join one thing to another

cit.quote: The computer should have been connected to the printer
Connect the two red wires together

sense.def: to make it possible for a telephone or a computer to be used for communicating with others

cit.quote: Has the telephone been connected yet

sense.def: a rela- tionship between things

cit.quote: There is a definite connection between smoking and lung cancer

sense.def: a bus, train or plane which you catch after getting off anoth- er means of transport

cit.quote: My train was late and I missed my connection to Bir- mingham

sense.def: a particular way of com- municating remotely

cit.quote: a low connec- tion charge
Is there a reliable phone connection?

sense.def: a point at which two dif- ferent pieces of equipment join

cit.quote: There is a loose connection somewhere

sense.def: connections people you know

cit.quote: He has business connections in Argentina

entry.re: in connection with relat- ing to ć I'm writing in connection with your visit

sense.def: to defeat peo- ple by force

cit.quote: The Romans had con- quered most of Europe

sense.def: to change a negative emotion or type of behaviour successfully

cit.quote: I eventually conquered my fear of flying

sense.def: a feeling that you have done right or wrong
working carefully and well

cit.quote: She's a very conscientious worker

sense.def: awake and able to know what is happening around you

cit.quote: She was conscious during the minor operation on her toe

sense.re: a con- scious decision a decision which you have thought carefully about ć Refusing the offer was a conscious decision on his part. ć He made a conscious deci- sion to try to avoid her in future

sense.def: in a de- liberate or active way

cit.quote: I wasn't con- sciously ignoring her -I just didn't no- tice her
He doesn't consciously re- member locking the door

sense.def: the fact of being conscious
sense.re: to lose consciousness to become unconscious

sense.def: following one after the other
something which happens because of something else

cit.quote: If we lose this order, the consequences for the firm will be disastrous
Smoking has serious health consequences

sense.def: importance
sense.re: of no consequence not im- portant ć What he thinks about the situ- ation is of no consequence

entry.re: as a con- sequence as a result ć We queued for two hours in the rain, and as a conse- quence all of us got colds

sense.def: the careful use of things such as energy or natural resources

cit.quote: The company is spending more money on energy conser- vation

sense.def: not wanting to change

cit.quote: He has very conservative views

sense.def: to think carefully about something

cit.quote: Please consider seriously the offer which we are making
We have to consider the position of the children

sense.def: to think

cit.quote: Do you consider him the right man for the job?
She is considered (to be) one of the best lawyers in town

sense.re: all things considered used for saying that you have thought about all aspects of a situ- ation, including the bad ones ć All things considered, the party went off quite well

sense.def: fairly large

cit.quote: He lost a consider- able amount of money at the horse race

sense.def: to a fairly large extent
careful thought

cit.quote: We are giving serious consideration to the possibility of moving the head office to Scotland

sense.re: to take something into consideration to think about something when making a decision ć The age of the children has to be taken into consideration
under consideration being thought about ć The matter is under consideration

sense.def: something which has an effect on a de- cision

cit.quote: The safety of the children is more important than all other consider- ations

sense.def: used to say that one thing affects another

cit.quote: He plays the vi- olin extremely well, considering he's only five
He ought to be more grate- ful, considering the amount of help you have given him

sense.def: a letter representing a sound which is produced by partly stopping the air going out of the mouth
a police officer of the lowest rank
not changing or stopping

cit.quote: The constant noise of music from the bar next door drives me mad

sense.def: a number or thing which does not change

cit.quote: Death and taxes are the only constants in life
The speed of light is a scientific con- stant

sense.def: all the time
to build something

cit.quote: The wings are constructed of aluminium
The airport was con- structed in 1995

sense.def: the act of building

cit.quote: The construction of the new stadium took three years

sense.re: un- der construction being built ć The new airport is still under construction

sense.def: something which has been built
to ask some- one for advice

cit.quote: He consulted his bank about transferring his account

sense.def: to look at something to get information

cit.quote: After consulting the map they decided to go north

sense.def: an expert who gives advice

cit.quote: His tax con- sultant advised him to sell the shares

sense.def: a senior hospital doctor who is an expert in a particular medical condition or ill- ness

cit.quote: We'll make an appointment for you to see a consultant

sense.def: to eat or drink something

cit.quote: The guests consumed over a hundred hamburgers

sense.def: to use something up

cit.quote: The world's natural re- sources are being consumed at an alarming rate
The new car consumes about half the amount of petrol of an or- dinary car

sense.def: a person or company that buys goods or services

cit.quote: Consumers are buying more from su- permarkets and less from small shops
Gas consumers are protesting at the in- crease in prices

sense.def: an act of touching

cit.quote: Avoid any contact between the acid and the skin
Anyone who has been in physical contact with the patient must consult their doctor immediately

sense.def: the act of communicating with some- one

cit.quote: We don't have much contact with our old friends in Australia

sense.re: to get in contact with someone to write to some- one or talk to them on the telephone

sense.def: to write to someone or talk to them on the telephone

cit.quote: He tried to contact his office by phone
Can you contact the ticket office immediately

sense.def: to hold an amount, or to have an amount inside

cit.quote: The bottle contains acid
The enve- lope contained a cheque for £1,000
A barrel contains 250 litres
I have lost a briefcase containing important docu- ments

sense.def: to limit or prevent something harmful or unpleasant

cit.quote: The army tried to contain the advance of the enemy forces
The party is attempting to con- tain the revolt among its members

sense.def: an object such as a box or bottle which holds something else

cit.quote: We need a container for all this rubbish
The gas is shipped in strong metal containers

sense.def: of the present time

cit.quote: contempo- rary art

sense.def: a person who lives at the same time as someone

cit.quote: Shake- speare and his contemporaries
He is one of my contemporaries from school

sense.def: a person who takes part in a competition, espe- cially someone who is likely to win

cit.quote: He's a definite contender for the world title

sense.def: the amount of something which is contained in a sub- stance

cit.quote: Dried fruit has a higher sugar content than fresh fruit

sense.def: things which are inside something

cit.quote: The contents of the bottle spilled onto the carpet

sense.def: the list of chapters in a book, usually printed at the beginning
happy with what is happening in your life ˽ content to happy to

cit.quote: She was content to sit in the sun and wait

sense.re: content with satisfied with ć If you are not con- tent with the way the car runs, bring it back and we will look at it again

sense.def: a feeling of satisfaction
sense.re: to your heart's content as much as you want ć You can play the piano to your heart's content. ć Living by the sea, they can go sailing to their heart's content

sense.def: satis- fied and happy
any event or situation in which people compete with each other

cit.quote: an international sports contest
Only two people entered the leadership contest

sense.def: to compete with other people to achieve a position

cit.quote: There are four candidates contesting the championship

sense.def: to say that you dis- agree with what is written in a legal doc- ument
a per- son who takes part in a competition

cit.quote: The two contestants shook hands before the match

sense.def: the other words which surround a particular word in a piece of writing and which help to show its meaning

cit.quote: Even if you don't know what a word means, you can sometimes guess its meaning from the context

sense.re: taken out of context show- ing only part of what someone said or wrote, so that the meaning is changed ć My words have been taken out of context -I said the book was 'one of the best' not 'the best' I'd read

sense.def: one of the seven large land areas in the world, e.g. Africa or Europe
the main land area of Europe, as compared with the islands of the United Kingdom

cit.quote: They go to the Continent on holiday each year, sometimes to France, some- times to Switzerland

sense.re: on the Conti- nent in the main part of Europe

sense.def: referring to a continent
referring to or typical of Europe excluding the Unit- ed Kingdom
happening many times in a period of time

cit.quote: We have experienced a period of continual change

sense.def: happening fre- quently in a way that is annoying

cit.quote: The computer has given us continual prob- lems ever since we bought it

sense.def: to go on do- ing something or happening

cit.quote: He con- tinued working, even though everyone else had gone home
The engine con- tinued to send out clouds of black smoke
The meeting started at 10 a.m. and continued until 6 p.m
The show continued with some children's dances

sense.def: without stopping or without a break

cit.quote: She has been in continuous pain for three days
A continuous white line on the road means that you are not allowed to overtake

sense.def: without a break
a legal agreement

cit.quote: I don't agree with some of the conditions of the contract

sense.re: under contract bound by the conditions of a contract ć The company is under con- tract to a French supermarket

sense.def: to be- come smaller

cit.quote: Metal contracts when it gets cold, and expands when it is hot

sense.def: to make an official agreement to do some work

cit.quote: to contract to supply spare parts or to contract for the supply of spare parts

sense.def: to say that what someone else says is not true

cit.quote: They didn't dare contradict their mother

sense.def: to be different from what has been said before

cit.quote: What you have just said contradicts what you said yester- day

sense.def: a differ- ence between two things

cit.quote: the contrast in weather between the north and the south of the country
The two cities are in sharp contrast

sense.re: in contrast to as opposed to ć He is quite short, in con- trast to his sister who is very tall. ć The north of the country is green and wood- ed in contrast to the south which is dry and sandy

sense.def: to be obvi- ously different from

cit.quote: His formal letter contrasted with his friendly conversa- tion on the telephone

sense.def: to help something to happen

cit.quote: The gov- ernment's policies have contributed to a feeling of anxiety among teachers

sense.def: to give money to help to pay for some- thing, especially when other people are also giving

cit.quote: We were asked to contrib- ute to a charity
Everyone was asked to contribute to the receptionist's leav- ing present

entry.re: thing that someone does to help some- thing to happen ć I want to thank you for your enormous contribution to the success of the project

sense.def: some- thing, usually money, given to help to pay for something

cit.quote: She makes monthly contributions to the Red Cross

sense.def: a per- son or organisation that contributes to something
the fact of keeping someone or something in order or being able to direct them

cit.quote: He lost control of his business and resigned
The club is under the control of three people

sense.def: the ability to get people to do what you want

cit.quote: The teacher has no control over the class

sense.def: to keep something in order, to direct or limit something

cit.quote: The police couldn't control the crowds
There was nobody there to control the traffic
We must try to control the sales of foreign cars
The government controls the price of meat

sense.re: to control a business to have the power to direct the way a business is run

cit.quote: The business is controlled by a com- pany based in Luxembourg

sense.def: kept under control
not causing any practical problems

cit.quote: Six o'clock in the morning is not a very convenient time for a meeting
A bank draft is a convenient way of sending money abroad

sense.def: in a convenient way
ordinary or usual

cit.quote: For your in- terview it's best to wear a conventional suit

sense.def: an occasion on which two or more peo- ple talk to each other about something

cit.quote: We had a long conversation with the bank manager
Why did he suddenly change the subject of the conversation

sense.def: a criminal who has been sent to prison

cit.quote: The po- lice are searching for two escaped con- victs

sense.def: to prove in court that someone is guilty

cit.quote: She was convicted of theft

sense.def: very certain

cit.quote: She's convinced that she's right

sense.def: a person who gets food ready

cit.quote: He worked as a cook in a pub during the summer

sense.def: to get food ready for eating, especially by heating it

cit.quote: It's my turn to cook the dinner tonight
How do you cook cabbage

sense.def: a large piece of kitchen equipment, used for cooking food
usually US a small, flat hard sweet cake

cit.quote: She bought a packet of cookies

sense.note: NOTE: The British English term is biscuit

sense.def: a computer file sent to your computer by a website when you visit it. It stores information about you which can be used when you next visit the website
cold in a pleasant way, or colder than you would like or than you expect

cit.quote: It was hot on deck but cool down below
Wines should be stored in a cool cellar
It gets cool in the evenings in September

sense.def: not friend- ly or not enthusiastic

cit.quote: I got a cool re- ception when I arrived half an hour late
Their proposal got a cool response

sense.re: to be cool towards someone to be un- friendly to someone or unenthusiastic about something ć She was rather cool towards me last time we met

cit.quote: My col- leagues were cool towards the plan un- fortunately

sense.def: calm

cit.quote: The nurses re- mained cool and professional

sense.def: fash- ionable

cit.quote: They thought it was cool to wear white trainers

sense.def: good

cit.quote: a cool party
a really cool idea

sense.def: to make something cool; to become cool

cit.quote: She boiled the jam for several hours and then put it aside to cool

sense.def: a colder area which is pleasant

cit.quote: After the heat of the town centre, it is nice to sit in the cool of the garden

sense.def: the state of being calm

cit.quote: As soon as the reporters started to ask her questions she lost her cool

entry.re: to be cool with something to be satisfied with something (informal) ć We can go tomorrow -I'm cool with that

sense.def: a reddish metal which turns green when exposed to air

cit.quote: Copper is a good conductor of elec- tricity
The end of the copper wire should be attached to the terminal

sense.def: something made to look the same as something else

cit.quote: This is an exact copy of the painting by Pi- casso

entry.re: cut back phrasal verb to reduce spend- ing ć We are having to cut back on staff costs
cut down phrasal verb to make a tree fall down with a tool such as a saw ć He cut the tree down or cut down the tree

cut off phrasal verb 1. to take away a small part of something using a sharp tool such as a knife ć She cut off a little piece of string. ć He cut off two slices of ham. 2. to stop someone from being with someone else, or from or reaching a place ć She was cut off from her friends by a crowd of policemen. ć The village was cut off by the snow

cut out phrasal verb 1. to remove something from something larger ć She cut an advertisement out of the newspa- per. 2. to remove a part of something larger ć We had to cut out all the extras from our order because they cost too much. 3. to stop doing or eating some- thing ć She's decided to cut out sweet things so as to lose weight. ˽ cut it out! stop doing that! (informal) ȣ
to be cut out for something to be ideally suited for something ć I don't think he's cut out for an office job
cut up phrasal verb to make something into small pieces by cutting it ć She cut the old towel up into little pieces. ć Can you cut up the meat for the children

entry.re: that will do that's enough ȣ
to make do with to accept something which is not as good as you wanted ć The ordinary plates are all dirty, so we will have to make do with paper ones. do
away with phrasal verb to get rid of something

do up phrasal verb 1. to attach some- thing ć He's still a baby and he can't do his buttons up properly. ć Can you do up the zip at the back of my dress? 2. to repair something and make it like new ć They bought an old cottage and did it up. ć He's looking for an old sports car to do up

do with phrasal verb 1. to be related or connected to ć It has nothing to do with us. ć It is something to do with my new book. 2. to put something somewhere ć What have you done with the newspa- per? 3. to need something ć After that long walk I could do with a cup of tea. ć The car could do with a wash
do without phrasal verb not to have something, to manage without some- thing

sense.note: NOTE: eighth is usually written 8th in dates: April 8th, 1999; September 8th, 1866 (American style is September 8, 1866), say 'the eighth of September' or 'September the eighth' (American style is 'Septem- ber eighth'
with names of kings and queens, eighth is usually written VIII: King Henry VIII

sense.def: relat- ing to number 80 in a series

sense.re: the eighties the numbers between 80 and 89

sense.def: one or the other

sense.def: each of two; both

sense.def: used with two negatives to show that two people or things are similar in some way

sense.def: able to stretch and contract

sense.def: the joint in the mid- dle of your arm

sense.def: a more polite word than "old" used for describing someone who has had a long life

sense.def: energy used to make light, heat, or power

sense.def: the science of the movement of electricity in electronic equipment
a basic chemical substance
a basic part of something

cit.quote: I think we have all the ele- ments of a settlement

sense.def: a natural envi- ronment

cit.quote: The vicar is in his element when he's talking about cricket

sense.def: a part of a piece of equipment which makes, e.g. water hot

sense.def: a very large African or Indian animal, with large ears, a trunk and two long teeth called 'tusks
a machine for moving people up or down from floor to floor inside a building

sense.def: the number 11

sense.def: re- lating to number 11 in a series

cit.quote: The eleventh of July/July the eleventh (July 11th)
Today's the tenth, so tomorrow must be the eleventh
That's the elev- enth complaint we've received this week
It's his eleventh birthday next month

Every- one else had already left
Who else was at the meeting

entry.re: or else or if not ć We could do it now, or else wait till John comes. ć You must have a ticket, or else you will be thrown off the train by the inspector

sense.def: some- where else, in another place

sense.def: a system of sending messages from one computer to another, using telephone lines

cit.quote: You can contact me by phone or email if you want

sense.def: to send a message to someone using email

cit.quote: I emailed him about the meeting

sense.def: to make someone feel uncomfortable in front of other people, e.g. by talking about something that they would prefer other people not to know about
uncomfortable or ashamed, and not knowing what to do

cit.quote: She gave an em- barrassed laugh, and said she had for- gotten to bring the present

sense.def: making a person feel embarrassed

cit.quote: It was very embarrassing when he told everyone about my mistake

sense.def: the first state of a living organism

cit.quote: a human embryo

sense.def: to come into existence as something

cit.quote: It was only af- ter the election that he emerged as party leader

sense.def: to become known

cit.quote: It soon emerged that the Prime Minister knew nothing about what was happening

sense.def: a dan- gerous situation such as a fire or an ac- cident, where decisions have to be taken quickly

cit.quote: Phone for an ambulance - this is an emergency

sense.def: a strong feeling

cit.quote: Hatred and love are two of the most powerful emotions

sense.pc: He tried to hide his emotions when he made his speech

sense.def: causing you to feel emotion, or showing emotion

cit.quote: Saying goodbye was an emo- tional time for us all

sense.def: the act of showing the importance of something, usually in speech

cit.quote: Don't put too much emphasis on his age

sense.def: how loud your voice is when you pronounce a word or phrase

sense.def: to show how important you feel something is, by saying it more loudly or slowly

cit.quote: Please emphasise that the meeting must start on time

sense.def: several separate countries ruled by a central government

sense.def: to give some- one regular paid work

sense.def: to use something

sense.def: a person who is employed

sense.def: a person or organisation that gives work to people and pays them

The car fac- tory is the biggest employer in the area

sense.def: reg- ular paid work
with nothing inside, or with no people present

cit.quote: When we opened it, the box was empty
Take an empty pot and fill it with soil
The fridge is empty -we'll have to go out to eat
The ski resorts are empty because there is no snow

sense.def: to make some- thing empty

cit.quote: She emptied the clothes out of the suitcase

sense.def: to make it possi- ble for someone to do something

sense.def: to put some- thing inside an envelope with a letter

sense.def: to put a wall or fence round an area of land

sense.def: sur- rounded on all sides

cit.quote: an enclosed space

sense.def: to meet someone or something

sense.def: to make it easier for something to happen

cit.quote: Leaving your credit cards on your desk encourages people to steal or encourag- es stealing

sense.def: to help someone to do something by giving them confidence

cit.quote: He encouraged me to apply for the job
I always felt encouraged by his inter- est in what I was doing

sense.def: a reference book containing articles on many subjects of human knowledge, usually presented in alphabetical order
a reference book containing articles on a single subject, arranged usually in alphabetical order

cit.quote: a gardening encyclopedia
the ency- clopedia of sport

sense.def: the last part of some- thing

cit.quote: She tied the two ends of the rib- bon together

Go down to the end of the road and then turn right

sense.re: to come to an end to be finished ć The work should come to an end next month

sense.def: the final part of a period of time

cit.quote: Can you wait until the end of the week?

sense.def: when some- thing ends, it reaches the point when it stops happening

cit.quote: The film ends with a wedding
The meeting ended with eve- ryone fighting on the floor
The con- cert should end at about 10 o'clock
The game ended in a draw

entry.re: in the end finally, at last ć In the end the teacher let him go home. ć In the end the shop had to call in the police
to make ends meet to have just enough money to live on ć I'm having trouble making ends meet
end up phrasal verb to finish in a par- ticular situation

sense.def: to try very hard to do something

sense.note: NOTE: The US spelling is en- deavor.

sense.def: the way a story finishes

cit.quote: I like films which have a hap- py ending
He told us so much of the story that we could guess the ending

sense.def: a person or coun- try that is not on friendly terms with an- other, and may try to harm them

sense.def: active and lively
the force or strength of a person

sense.def: a power which makes something work

sense.def: a machine which powers or drives something

sense.def: a ve- hicle which pulls a train

sense.def: a person who looks after and repairs technical equipment

cit.quote: There are not enough tele- phone engineers in the area

sense.def: a person whose job is to design mechanical, elec- trical or industrial equipment
the science or study of the design of techni- cal equipment

sense.note: NOTE: the word England is often used instead of Britain, and this is a mistake, as England is only one part of Great Britain; note also the capital: London; people: the English; language: Eng- lish; currency: pound sterling

sense.def: relating to England

cit.quote: the beautiful English coun- tryside
Is the English weather really as bad as it is made out to be?
I think she is English, although she speaks with an Australian accent

sense.note: NOTE: English is often used instead of British. This is a mistake as England is only one part of Great Britain. Do not say the English Prime Minister, say the British Prime Minister

sense.def: the English language as a subject of study in school or univer- sity

cit.quote: She's good at maths but not so good at English

sense.def: a man from England
sense.note: NOTE: The plural is Eng- lishmen.

sense.def: a woman from England
sense.note: NOTE: The plu- ral is Englishwomen

sense.def: to increase the value or power of something

cit.quote: Slot in this new memory board to enhance your computer memory

sense.def: to get pleasure from something

cit.quote: Have you enjoyed the hol- iday so far?

sense.def: giv- ing pleasure
pleas- ure
to make some- thing bigger

cit.quote: Could you enlarge this photograph

cit.quote: The ballroom is absolutely enormous

sense.def: very much
as much as is needed

sense.def: as much of some- thing as is needed

sense.def: as much as is needed

cit.quote: This box isn't big enough for all these books

sense.def: to make sure of something

sense.def: to go into or to come into a place

sense.def: to decide to take part in a race or competition

sense.def: to write information on a book or a form, or to type informa- tion into a computer system

sense.def: the key on a keyboard which you press when you have finished keying something, or when you want to start a new line

cit.quote: To log on to the sys- tem, type your password and press enter. ı entrance, entry

things such as films and shows that peo- ple enjoy watching

sense.def: a person who takes part in a race, examination or com- petition

sense.def: the door or opening where you go into a place

sense.def: a folded pa- per cover for sending letters in

sense.def: feeling or showing in an unhappy way that you would like to have something that some- one else has
the land, the water, the air and the build- ings which are around us, and the condi- tions in which we live

cit.quote: The environ- ment in the office is not good for con- centrated work

sense.def: relating to the environment

sense.def: an unhappy feeling that you would like to have something which someone else has

sense.def: to have the unhappy feeling that you would like to have something that someone else has

having exactly the same amount as something else

sense.def: to be ex- actly the same as

sense.def: to give a particular result

cit.quote: Two plus two equals four

sense.note: NOTE: equals -equalling - equalled. The US spelling is equaling -equaled.

sense.def: a person who is on the same level as someone else

sense.def: in exactly the same way

cit.quote: They are all equally guilty

sense.note: NOTE: no plu- ral: for one item say a piece of equip- ment.)

sense.def: something that is wrong, especially a mistake in writing or speaking

sense.def: to throw out fire and other very hot sub- stances

sense.def: used for showing that something is the case to a great degree

sense.def: used for showing that something is more important or true

sense.def: which is very important or which you must have

sense.def: used for saying what is the most true, or the most important fact

sense.def: to create something, to set something up

sense.def: to discover or prove some- thing

sense.def: the act of creating something

sense.note: NOTE: no plu- ral in this sense

sense.def: a business; an or- ganisation

sense.def: the most important people in soci- ety, especially those who are in authori- ty

cit.quote: He spent a lot of his life fighting against the Establishment

sense.def: a large area of land belonging to one owner

sense.def: a group of houses on one piece of land, usually all built at the same time
a calculation or guess which shows the amount of something you think there is, or its worth or cost

cit.quote: I wasn't in when they came to read the gas meter, so this bill is only an estimate

sense.re: she gave me a rough estimate she gave me an approximate calculation

sense.def: to calculate or guess how much you think something will cost or is worth

cit.quote: I estimate that it will cost £100,000

sense.def: and so on, and other things like this

cit.quote: Fruit such as oranges, bananas, etc

sense.def: the unit of money used by most countries in the European Union

cit.quote: Many articles are priced in eu- ros

sense.note: NOTE: written Ä before num- bers: Ä250

sense.def: the continent of Europe, the part of the world to the west of Asia, extending from Russia to Ireland

sense.def: the same area, but not including the UK

sense.def: re- lating to Europe
to make a judgement about something after think- ing carefully about it

cit.quote: The students were asked to evaluate the usefulness of the lessons

sense.def: the act of evaluating something, or the judgement made in this way
to turn into steam by being heated

cit.quote: Wa- ter gradually evaporates from the soil

sense.def: flat, level

cit.quote: The road has a smooth, even surface

sense.def: not changing

cit.quote: They kept up an even pace for miles

sense.def: used for showing surprise or making an expression stronger

cit.quote: He doesn't even like strawberries

She's tall, but her sister is even taller

sense.def: the late part of the day, when it starts to get dark

The evening meal is served from 7.30 to 10.30

sense.def: in an equal way
something important which happens

cit.quote: the events leading up to the war
A baby's first birthday is always a very happy event

sense.def: in the end

form.pron: used with negatives and in questions

cit.quote: Nothing ever happens here

sense.def: a tree which keeps its leaves all winter

cit.quote: Holly and other evergreens can be used as decorations in winter

sense.def: each

cit.quote: It rained every day during the holidays

sense.def: with a particular amount of time or distance in between

cit.quote: The medicine is to be taken every four hours

sense.def: same as everyone
all the people involved in a particular situation

cit.quote: Everyone has to die some day
If everybody is here, we can start
Eve- ryone must show their passport

sense.note: NOTE: everyone and everybody are fol- lowed by they, their, themselves, etc., but the verb stays

form.pron: singular: Is eve- ryone enjoying themselves? Not eve- rybody likes pop music, do they?

sense.def: everyone else all the other people

cit.quote: Only Maggie could come -everyone else was too busy

sense.def: all things

cit.quote: Did you bring everything you need?

sense.def: things in general

cit.quote: Everything was dark in the street

sense.def: in all places

cit.quote: There were papers lying about everywhere

sense.def: a fact which proves that something really exists or has happened

cit.quote: The bloodstains on his coat were clear evidence of the crime

sense.def: obvious
morally very bad

cit.quote: She's considered to be an evil woman

sense.def: used for showing that a person used to have a particular job or relationship

cit.quote: an ex-soldier

sense.def: completely ac- curate, with no more or no less

sense.def: not more, not less

sense.def: to make things seem, e.g. worse, better, bigger than they really are

sense.def: same as examina- tion

sense.def: an occasion on which someone looks at something to see if it works properly, or to see if something is wrong

sense.def: a written or spoken test

sense.note: NOTE: often shortened to exam in this sense

sense.def: to look carefully at something to see what is in it, or what it is like

sense.def: to test a stu- dent

sense.def: a person who conducts an exam
something chosen to show something

cit.quote: This is a good example of French architecture of the eleventh century

sense.re: to set an exam- ple to do things well or properly your- self, so that other people can copy you ć He sets everyone a good example by get- ting into the office before 8.00 every morning
to make an example of someone to punish someone so that oth- ers will learn not to do what that person did ć Her teacher made an example of her by making her miss the class trip

sense.def: to go beyond something

cit.quote: The car was exceeding the speed limit

sense.def: very good

sense.note: NOTE: [all senses] Do not confuse with accept

sense.def: something that is not included

sense.def: to a very great degree, often so great as to be surprising
to give one thing and to get another thing back

sense.def: lively and happy because you think something good is going to happen

sense.def: making you feel excited

sense.def: full of activity, sometimes making you a little scared because you do not know what is going to happen

sense.def: to say some- thing loudly and suddenly
not to include someone or something

sense.def: a reason given for doing something wrong, or for not doing what was expected

cit.quote: His excuse for not coming was that he forgot the date

sense.def: to forgive someone for making a small mistake

entry.re: back on phrasal verb to do or use something only after all other things have failed

fall off phrasal verb to become fewer ć The number of customers starts to fall off after 4 o'clock

fall out phrasal verb 1. to drop to the ground after having been in something ć We put cushions on the floor next to the bed in case she fell out. 2. to have an argument ć They fell out over the bill for drinks

sense.note: NOTE: gets -getting -got / ɒt/ - has got or

entry.re: get going phrasal verb to start doing something, or to leave ć Come on, let's get going!

get across phrasal verb 1. to manage to cross something ć They got across the river on rafts. 2. to make someone understand something ć I'm trying to get across to the people in the office that they all have to work harder. ć We just can't seem to get our message across
get along phrasal verb to manage ć She got along quite well when her moth- er was away on holiday. ć We seem to get along very happily without the tele- phone. ć How are you getting along?

get around phrasal verb 1. to move from place to place ć Since he had his accident he gets around on two sticks. 2. (of news) to be heard by a lot of people ć The news soon got around that they were married
get at phrasal verb to reach something ć You'll need to stand on a chair to get at the jam jar on the top shelf
get away phrasal verb to escape ć The robbers got away in a stolen car

get back phrasal verb 1. to return ć They got back home very late. ć When did they get back from the cinema? 2. to get something again which you had be- fore ć I got my money back after I had complained to the manager
get down phrasal verb 1

sense.def: to go back down onto the ground

cit.quote: The cat climbed up the tree and couldn't get down
He got down off the ladder

sense.def: to bring something down

cit.quote: Can you get my suitcase down for me?
get in phrasal verb

sense.def: to go inside a place or a vehicle

cit.quote: Get in! -the train's going to leave

sense.def: to arrive home or at the office

cit.quote: What time did you get in last night?
Because of the train strike, we didn't get in until eleven o'clock

sense.def: to ask some- one to come to do a job

cit.quote: We'll get a builder in to mend the wall

entry.re: get into phrasal verb to go inside a place or a vehicle ć They got into the back of the car. ć I was just getting into bed when the phone rang. ć The bur- glars got into the building through a window on the ground floor

get off phrasal verb to come down from or out of a form of transport such as a car, bus, train or plane ć She got off her bicycle at the red light. ć If you want the post office, you should get off at the next stop. ć You have to get off the train at South Kensington

get on phrasal verb 1. to go onto a form of transport such as a car, bus, train or plane ć They got on the bus at the bank. ć The policeman got on his bike and rode away. 2. to become old ć He's getting on and can't work as hard as he used to
get out phrasal verb to go out of a place or a vehicle ć The bus stopped and the driver got out. ć The burglars got out through the front door
get over phrasal verb 1. to climb over something ć They got over the wall into the garden. 2. to recover from an illness ć He's got over his flu
get through phrasal verb 1. to manage to go through something ć The cows got through the hole in the fence. 2. to be successful ć He got through his exams, so he is now a qualified engineer
get up phrasal verb 1. to get out of bed ć He went to bed so late that he didn't get up until 11 o'clock

30 if we are going to leave on time

sense.def: without getting annoyed
the act of keep- ing guard by walking or driving in one direction and then back again

sense.def: a group of people keeping guard

sense.def: to keep guard on a place by walk- ing or driving up and down

pay up phrasal verb to pay all the mon- ey which you owe ć The tourist paid up quickly when the taxi driver called the police

sense.def: more than

sense.def: a long green case in which some small vegetables such as peas or beans grow

to poke out of somewhere to appear through a hole or small space ć A red- faced man poked his head out of the window. ć A red handkerchief was pok- ing out of his pocket

entry.re: to poke fun at someone or something to laugh at someone or something in an unkind way ć He poked fun at the maths teach- er. ć She poked fun at his odd hat

gramGrp.pos: twenty pounds but a twenty-pound note.)

pull out phrasal verb 1. to take some- thing out by pulling ć They used a rope to pull the car out of the river. 2. to drive a car away from the side of the road ć He forgot to signal as he was pulling out. ć Don't pull out into the main road until you can see that there is nothing coming
pull over phrasal verb to drive a car to- wards the side of the road and stop ć The police car signalled to him to pull over
pull up phrasal verb 1. to bring some- thing closer ć Pull your chair up to the window

put down phrasal verb 1. to place something lower down onto a surface ć He put his suitcase down on the floor beside him. 2. to kill an animal that is old or ill, painlessly using drugs ć The cat will have to be put down

put in phrasal verb 1. to place some- thing inside something ć I forgot to put in my pyjamas when I packed the case. 2. to fix something such as a system or a large piece of equipment in place so that it can be used ć The first thing we have to do with the cottage is to put in central heating

put off phrasal verb 1. to arrange for something to take place later ć We have put the meeting off until next month. 2. to take someone's attention so that they cannot do things properly ć Stop mak- ing that strange noise, it's putting me off my work. 3. to say something that makes someone decide not to do something ć He told a story about cows that put me off my food. ć I was going to see the film, but my brother said something which put me off

sense.def: a choice or series of things which are available

sense.def: a distance which you can go; a distance over which you can see or hear

sense.def: a series of buildings or mountains in line

sense.def: ˽ to range from include all types between two limits

cit.quote: The sizes range from small to extra large

The quality of this year's examination papers ranged from excel- lent to very poor

sense.def: an official position in the army, the police force or a similar organisation

sense.def: done very quick- ly or happening very quickly

sense.def: quickly
not usual or common

sense.def: almost never

cit.quote: I rarely buy a Sunday newspaper

sense.def: a mass of red spots on your skin, which stays for a time and then disappears

cit.quote: She had a rash on her arms

sense.def: done without think- ing carefully or sensibly

sense.def: a small furry animal like a large mouse which has a long tail and can carry disease
a number shown as a proportion of another
how frequently something is done or how often some- thing happens

sense.def: a level of payment

sense.def: speed

sense.def: to a slight degree

sense.def: an amount of some- thing measured in relation to another amount

cit.quote: the ratio of successes to fail- ures

sense.def: to make a repeated noise like two pieces of wood hitting each other

sense.def: a beam of light or heat

sense.def: an instrument with a very sharp blade for removing hair from the face or body
how far you can stretch out your hand

cit.quote: Keep the medi- cine bottle out of the reach of the chil- dren

sense.def: to stretch out your hand in order to touch or take something

cit.quote: She reached across the table and took some meat from my plate

sense.def: to arrive at a place

sense.def: to get to a certain level

sense.def: to do or to say some- thing as a result of something that some- one else does or says

sense.def: a thing done or said as a result of something else

sense.def: a process of chemical change

sense.def: to look at and under- stand written words

sense.def: to look at and understand written music

sense.def: to understand the mean- ing of data from something such as a computer disk or a piece of electronic equipment

sense.def: to speak the words of something which is written

sense.note: NOTE: reads -reading -read) read aloud, read out phrasal verb to speak the words you are reading

sense.def: a person who reads, especially a person who reads regularly or who reads a particular newspaper or type of book

sense.def: a school book to help children to learn to read

sense.def: the act of look- ing at and understanding written words

sense.def: an occasion when someone speaks the words of something which is written

sense.def: prepared for something

cit.quote: Hold on -I'll be ready in two minutes

sense.def: used for emphasising something

sense.def: which exists in the world, not only in someone's imagination or in stories

cit.quote: She believes fairies are real

sense.def: to un- derstand clearly something that you did not understand before

sense.def: situations which are real and not imaginary

sense.def: ȣ in reality in fact

sense.def: in fact

cit.quote: The building really belongs to my father

sense.def: used to show surprise

cit.quote: She's not really French, is she?
She doesn't like ap- ples. -Really, how strange!

sense.def: the part at the back

sense.def: at the back

cit.quote: The children sat in the rear seats in the car

sense.def: to look after animals or children as they are growing up

sense.def: to rise up, or to lift something up

sense.def: a thing which explains why something has happened

sense.def: the ability to make sen- sible judgments

sense.def: to think or to plan some- thing carefully and sensibly

cit.quote: He rea- soned that any work is better than no work, so he took the job
If you take the time to reason it out, you'll find a so- lution to the problem

entry.re: it stands to reason it is reasonable ć It stands to reason that he wants to join his father's firm
to see reason to see that some- one's argument is right or reasonable ć She was going to report her neighbours to the police, but in the end we got her to see reason
within reason to a sensi- ble degree, in a sensible way ć The chil- dren get £5 pocket money each week, and we let them spend it as they like, within reason

sense.def: sensible

cit.quote: The manager of the shop was very reasonable when she tried to explain that she had left her credit cards at home

sense.def: not expensive

cit.quote: The hotel's charges are quite reasonable

sense.def: to fight against some- one or something

sense.def: the act of asking for products to be returned, or the act of ordering someone to return

sense.def: to remember something

sense.def: to tell a government official to come home from a foreign country

sense.def: a piece of paper that shows you have paid for something or shows you have received something

sense.def: only a short time ago

sense.def: the way in which people react to something that happens or to someone who arrives

sense.def: the quality of the sound on a radio or the sound and pic- ture of a TV broadcast

instructions for cooking food

sense.def: to calculate something or to estimate something

sense.def: to have an opinion about something or to make a judgment about something

to know someone or something because you have seen him or her or it before

coloured like the col- our of blood

entry.re: . to be about some- thing or someone ć Do you think he was referring to me when he said some staff would have to leave? 2. to look into something for information ć He re- ferred to his diary to see if he had a free afternoon. 3. to pass a problem to some- one to decide ć We have referred your complaint to our head office. ć He was referred to an ear specialist by his GP. (NOTE: refers -referring -referred)

sense.def: a per- son who makes sure that a game is played according to the rules

an act of say- ing that you do not accept something

sense.def: an opinion of someone

sense.def: to have an opinion about someone

with regard to relating to ć With regard to your re- quest for extra funds

sense.def: to tell a story

sense.def: be- longing to the same family as

sense.def: relat- ing to or connected with

sense.def: a member of a family

sense.def: not upset or nervous

to stop holding something, or to stop keeping someone prisoner

The hostages were released last night

sense.def: to make something public

sense.def: which can be relied on or which can be trusted

a belief in gods or in one God

sense.def: to pay money to use a house, flat, office or car

sense.def: to make something work which is broken or damaged

sense.def: to say something again

to put something back where it was before

cit.quote: Please re- place the books correctly on the shelves

sense.def: a thing which is used to replace some- thing

sense.def: the act of replacing something with something else

sense.def: to do or make something in exactly the same way as before
an answer, espe- cially to a letter or telephone call

sense.def: to give or send an answer to something such as a message or letter

cit.quote: He never replies to my letters

sense.def: a description of what has happened or what will happen

sense.def: to go somewhere officially, or to say that you have arrived somewhere

to speak or act on behalf of someone or of a group of people

sense.def: to mean something, or to be a symbol of something g

cit.quote: The dark green on the map represents woods

sense.def: typical of all the people or things in a group

sense.def: to make a copy of something

sense.def: a cold-blooded animal which has skin covered with scales and which lays eggs
a system of government in which elected represent- atives have power and the leader is an elected or nominated president

sense.def: to save someone from a dangerous or difficult situation

sense.def: scientific study which tries to find out facts

sense.def: to study something in order to find out facts

sense.def: to feel annoyed be- cause of something that you think is un- fair

sense.def: an amount kept back in case it is needed in the future

entry.re: in reserve waiting to be used ć We're keeping the can of petrol in re- serve

sense.def: a large, usually artificial, lake where drinking water is kept for supplying a city

sense.def: who lives perma- nently in a place

sense.def: to give up a job

sense.def: a source of sup- ply for what is needed or used

sense.def: to show that you like or ap- prove of something

sense.def: something that you do or say as a reaction to some- thing

sense.def: the position of someone who must look after or deal with something

looking after something and so likely to be blamed if something goes wrong

sense.re: responsible to someone under the au- thority of someone ć She's directly re- sponsible to the sales manager

sense.def: reliable and able to be trusted to be sensible

sense.note: NOTE: Rest takes a singular verb when it refers to a

form.pron: singular: Here's the rest of the milk; Where's the rest of the string? The rest of the money has been lost

entry.re: It takes a plural verb when it refers to a plural: Here

form.pron: are the rest of the children; Where are the rest of the chairs? The rest of the books have been lost.

sense.def: to spend time relaxing or not us- ing energy

sense.def: a place where you can buy and eat a meal

sense.def: which makes you feel calm and relaxed
too nerv- ous, worried or full of energy to keep still

sense.def: to limit someone or something

sense.def: something which happens because of something else

show off phrasal verb 1. to show how much better than other people you think you are ć Don't watch her dancing about like that -she's just showing off. 2. to let a lot of people see something which you are proud of ć He drove past with the radio on very loud, showing off his new car

entry.re: shut down phrasal verb 1. to close completely ć The factory shut down for the holiday weekend. 2. to switch off an electrical system ć They had to shut down the factory because pollution lev- els were too high
shut in phrasal verb to lock someone inside a place

shut off phrasal verb 1. to switch something off ć Can you shut off the water while I mend the tap? 2. to stop access to ć We can shut off the dining room with folding doors. ć The house is shut off from the road by a high wall

shut out phrasal verb 1. to lock some- one outside a place ć I was shut out of the house because I'd left my keys in- side. ć If the dog keeps on barking you'll have to shut him out. 2. to stop light getting inside, or to stop people seeing inside ć Those thick curtains should shut out the light from the chil- dren's room. ć A high wall shuts out the view of the factory. 3. to stop thinking about something ć Try to shut out the memory of the accident

shut up phrasal verb 1. to close some- thing inside a place ć I hate being shut up indoors on a sunny day. 2. an impo- lite way of telling someone to stop talk- ing or to stop making a noise ć Tell those children to shut up -I'm trying to work. ć Shut up! -we're tired of listen- ing to your complaints. ć Once he starts talking it's impossible to shut him up

sense.def: to move round and round very fast

cit.quote: The earth is spinning in space
The plane was spinning out of control

sense.def: to make something turn round and round

cit.quote: The washing ma- chine spins the clothes to get the water out of them
He spun the wheel to make sure it turned freely

sense.def: to make a web

cit.quote: The spider has spun a web between the two posts

sense.def: the turning movement of a ball as it moves

cit.quote: He put so much spin on the ball that it bounced side- ways

entry.re: spin out phrasal verb to make some- thing last as long as possible

sense.def: a series of bones joined together from your skull down the middle of your back

cit.quote: He injured his spine playing rugby

sense.note: NOTE: The bones in the spine are the vertebrae

sense.def: a sharp part like a pin, on a plant, an- imal or fish

cit.quote: Did you know that lemon trees had spines?

sense.def: the back edge of a book, which usually has the title printed on it

cit.quote: The title and the author's name are printed on the front of the book and also on the spine

sense.def: a shape which is twisted round and round like a spring

cit.quote: He drew a spiral on the sheet of paper

sense.def: which twists round and round

cit.quote: A spiral staircase leads to the top of the tower

sense.def: the mental attitude which controls how someone behaves generally

cit.quote: She has a great spirit of fun
He had an independent spirit.

sense.def: feel- ings which are typical of a particular oc- casion
the part of a person that is said to still exist after death
alcohol
relating to the spirit or the soul

cit.quote: The church's main task is to give spiritual advice to its members

sense.def: bad feeling

cit.quote: They sprayed his car with white paint out of spite

sense.re: in spite of although some- thing happened or was done ć In spite of all his meetings, he still found time to ring his wife

cit.quote: We all enjoyed our- selves, in spite of the awful weather

sense.def: to annoy someone on purpose

cit.quote: He did it to spite his sister

sense.def: full of a nasty feelings against someone
a sound made when something falls into a liquid or when a liquid hits something hard

cit.quote: She fell into the pool with a loud splash
Lis- ten to the splash of the waves against the rocks

sense.def: to make a noise when something is dropped into it or when it hits something

cit.quote: I missed the ball and it splashed into the pool

sense.def: to make someone wet by sending liquid on to him or her

sense.def: to move through water, making a noise

cit.quote: He splashed his way through the shallow water to the rocks

sense.def: extreme- ly good or impressive
to divide something into parts

cit.quote: He split the log into small pieces with an axe

sense.def: to divide or come apart

cit.quote: My trousers were too tight -they split when I bent down

sense.def: to change something which was good so that it is no longer good

cit.quote: We had such bad weather that our camping holiday was spoilt

sense.def: to be too kind to someone, especially a child, so that he or she sometimes becomes badly be- haved

cit.quote: You'll spoil that child if you al- ways give in to him

sense.def: a soft material full of small holes used to make things like cushions

sense.def: a sea animal with a skeleton which is full of holes

sense.def: to wipe clean with a sponge

cit.quote: He sponged the kitchen table

sense.def: an object used for eating liquids and soft food, or for stir- ring food which is being cooked, with a handle at one end and a small bowl at the other,

cit.quote: Use a spoon to eat your pudding
We need a big spoon to serve the soup

sense.def: a game or games in- volving physical activity and competi- tion

cit.quote: Do you like watching sport on TV?

She doesn't play any sport at all

sense.def: a coloured mark, usually round

cit.quote: Her dress has a pattern of white and red spots

sense.def: a particular place

cit.quote: This is the exact spot where the queen died

sense.def: a small round mark or pimple on the skin

cit.quote: She suddenly came out in spots after eating fish

sense.def: to notice something or someone

cit.quote: The teacher didn't spot the mistake

sense.def: complete- ly clean, with no dirty marks at all
a tube on a container which is shaped for pouring liquid out of the container

cit.quote: You fill the kettle through the spout

sense.def: to damage a joint of the body by twisting it suddenly and vi- olently

cit.quote: He sprained his ankle jumping over the fence

sense.def: a condition where a joint is injured because of a sud- den violent movement

cit.quote: He is walking with a stick because of an ankle sprain

sense.def: to lie with your arms and legs spread out

cit.quote: He sprawled in his armchair and turned on the TV

sense.def: a mass of tiny drops of liquid

sense.def: to send out liquid in fine drops

They sprayed the room with disinfectant

sense.def: to arrange some- thing over a wide area

cit.quote: Spread the pa- per flat on the table

sense.def: to move over a wide area

sense.def: to cover a surface with a layer of something

cit.quote: She spread a white cloth over the table

sense.def: the action of moving over a wide area

sense.def: a soft food consisting of meat, fish or cheese, which you can spread on something such as bread

cit.quote: As snacks, they offered us water biscuits with cheese spread

sense.def: the season of the year between winter and summer

cit.quote: In spring all the trees start to grow new leaves

They started work last spring or in the spring of last year and they still haven't finished

sense.def: a wire which is twisted round and round and which goes back to its original shape after you have pulled it or pushed it

cit.quote: The mattress is so old the springs have burst through the cover
There's a spring to keep the door shut

sense.def: a place where a stream of water rushes out of the ground

cit.quote: The town of Bath was built in Roman times around hot springs

sense.def: to move sud- denly

cit.quote: Everyone sprang to life when the officer shouted
The door sprang open without anyone touching it

sense.def: to put small amounts of a liquid or powder over a surface by shaking
to run very fast over a short distance

cit.quote: I had to sprint to catch the bus
She sprinted down the track

sense.def: a new shoot of a plant

cit.quote: The vine is covered with new sprouts

sense.def: to produce new shoots

cit.quote: Throw those old potatoes away, they're starting to sprout
The bush had be- gun to sprout fresh green leaves

sense.re: to spurt out to come out in a strong jet ć Oil spurted out of the burst pipe

sense.def: to run fast sud- denly

cit.quote: He spurted past two runners and came in first

sense.def: a strong flow of liquid

cit.quote: They tried to block the spurts of water coming out of the pipe

sense.def: a person who is paid to try to find out secret information about the enemy or a rival group

cit.quote: He was ex- ecuted as a Russian spy

sense.def: to work as a spy

entry.re: NOTE: spies -spying -spied) ˽ to spy on someone to watch someone in secret, to find out what they are plan- ning to do ć We discovered that our neighbours had been spying on us

sense.def: a squalid room or building is dirty and unpleasant

cit.quote: The prisoners are kept in squalid con- ditions

sense.def: a shape with four equal sides and four right-angled corners

Graph paper is covered with small squares

sense.def: an open space in a town, with big buildings all round

cit.quote: The hotel is in the main square of the town, opposite the town hall
Red Square is in the middle of Moscow

sense.def: a number that is the result of multiplying another number by itself

cit.quote: 9 is the square of 3

sense.def: shaped like a square, with four equal sides and four right-angled corners

cit.quote: You can't fit six people round a small square table

sense.def: multiplied by it- self
to crush or to squeeze something

cit.quote: Hundreds of pas- sengers were squashed into the train
He sat on my hat and squashed it flat

sense.def: a fast game for two players played in an enclosed court, with a small, squashy rubber ball and light, long-han- dled rackets

cit.quote: He plays squash to un- wind after a day at the office

sense.def: to move your body close to the ground so that you are sit- ting on your heels

sense.def: a quiet high sound like the sound that a mouse makes

cit.quote: You can tell when someone comes into the garden by the squeak of the gate

sense.def: to make a squeak

cit.quote: That door squeaks -the hinges need oil- ing

sense.def: a loud high noise

cit.quote: The children let out squeals of delight when they saw the presents under the Christmas tree

sense.def: to make a loud high-pitched noise

cit.quote: She squealed when she heard she had won first prize

sense.def: the act of press- ing or crushing

cit.quote: I gave her hand a squeeze

sense.def: to press on some- thing or to press or crush something like a fruit or a tube to get something out of it

cit.quote: She squeezed my arm gently

sense.def: to force something, or to force your own body, into a small space

cit.quote: You can't squeeze six people into that little car

The cat managed to squeeze through the window

sense.def: a small red or grey wild animal with a large tail which lives in trees and eats nuts

cit.quote: The squir- rel sat up on a branch nibbling a nut

sense.def: to send out a thin powerful flow of liquid

cit.quote: Don't squirt so much washing-up liquid into the bowl

sense.def: street
saint
to push a sharp knife with force into someone or something

cit.quote: He was stabbed in the chest

sense.def: a deep wound made by the point of a knife

cit.quote: He died of stab wounds
