sense.def: which does not change

cit.quote: The hospital said his con- dition was stable

sense.def: a building for keeping a horse

cit.quote: My horse is not in his stable, who's riding him

sense.def: a pile or heap of things one on top of the other

The ware- house is stacked with boxes

sense.def: a large build- ing where crowds of people watch sport, with seats arranged around a sports field
sense.note: NOTE: The plural is stadiums or

sense.def: sta- dia
all the people who work in a company, school, college, or other organisation

cit.quote: She's on the school staff
Only staff can use this lift
A quarter of our staff are ill

He joined the staff last Monday
Three members of staff are away sick

sense.note: NOTE: staff refers to a group of people and so is often fol- lowed by a verb in the plural

sense.def: a raised floor, es- pecially where the actors perform in a theatre

cit.quote: The pop group came onto the stage and started to sing

sense.def: one of sev- eral points of development

cit.quote: the differ- ent stages of a production process
The first stage in the process is to grind the rock to powder

sense.def: a section of a long journey

sense.def: to put on or arrange a play, a show, a musical or other performance or event

cit.quote: The exhi- bition is being staged in the college li- brary

sense.def: to walk in way that is not steady or controlled, almost falling down

cit.quote: She managed to stagger across the road and into the police sta- tion

sense.def: to surprise someone very much

sense.def: to arrange some- thing such as holidays or working hours, so that they do not all begin and end at the same time

sense.def: the movement of someone who is stagger- ing

cit.quote: He walked with a noticeable stag- ger

sense.def: a mark which is diffi- cult to remove, e.g. ink or blood

sense.def: to make a mark of a differ- ent colour on something

cit.quote: If you eat those berries they will stain your teeth

sense.def: one step in a series of steps, going up or down inside a build- ing

cit.quote: He was sitting on the bottom stair

sense.def: a set of stairs which go from one floor in a building to another
a strong pointed piece of wood or metal, pushed into the ground to mark something, or to hold something up

cit.quote: They hammered stakes into the ground to put up a wire fence

sense.def: food which is stale is old and no longer fresh
the stem of a plant which holds a leaf, a flower or a fruit

cit.quote: Roses with very long stalks are more ex- pensive

sense.def: to stay near someone and watch him or her all the time, espe- cially in a way that is frightening or up- setting

sense.def: a place in a market where one person sells his or her goods

sense.def: to repeat sounds when speaking, e.g. because of feeling nervous

cit.quote: He stammers badly when making speeches

sense.def: a speech prob- lem that involves hesitating and repeat- ing sounds when speaking

cit.quote: Because of his stammer he was shy and reserved at school

sense.def: a little piece of paper with a price printed on it which you stick on a letter to show that you have paid for it to be sent by post

cit.quote: a first-class stamp

sense.def: a mark made on something

sense.def: to mark something with a stamp

cit.quote: They stamped my passport when I en- tered the country

sense.def: to walk, or to put your feet down, with loud or forceful steps

cit.quote: They stamped on the ants to kill them

sense.def: to be upright on your feet and not sitting or lying down

sense.def: to be upright

cit.quote: Only a few houses were still standing after the earthquake

sense.def: to accept something bad that continues

cit.quote: The of- fice is filthy -I don't know how you can stand working here

sense.def: something which holds something up

cit.quote: The pot of flowers fell off its stand

entry.re: stand for phrasal verb to have a mean- ing ć What do the letters BBC stand for?
stand out phrasal verb to be easily seen ć Their house stands out because it is painted pink. ć Her red hair makes her stand out in a crowd
stand up phrasal verb to get up from sitting ć When the teacher comes into the room all the children should stand up. ć He stood up to offer his seat to the old lady. stand
up for phrasal verb to try to de- fend someone or something in a diffi- cult situation ć He stood up for the rights of children. stand

up to phrasal verb 1. to oppose someone bravely ć No one was pre- pared to stand up to the head of depart- ment. 2. to be able to resist difficult conditions ć A carpet in a shop has to stand up to a lot of wear

sense.def: the level of quality something has

cit.quote: The stand- ard of service in this restaurant is very high

sense.def: a large official flag

sense.def: usual, not special

sense.def: on a tall pole
a piece of wire which is pushed through papers and bent over to hold them together

sense.def: to fasten pa- pers together with a staple or with sta- ples

sense.def: a shape that has several points like a star

cit.quote: Draw a big star and colour it red

sense.def: a famous person who is very well known to the public

cit.quote: football stars
Who is your favourite film star?

sense.def: to appear as a main character in a film or play

cit.quote: She starred in 'Gone with the Wind'

sense.def: to look at someone or something for a long time

cit.quote: She stared sadly out of the window at the rain

sense.def: a long fixed look

cit.quote: He gave her a stare and walked on

sense.def: the beginning of some- thing

cit.quote: The car won't start -the battery must be flat

entry.re: to start with first of all ć We have lots to do but to start with we'll do the washing up
start off phrasal verb 1. to begin ć We'll start off with soup and then have a meat dish. 2. to leave on a journey ć You can start off now, and I'll follow when I'm ready

sense.def: to make someone suddenly surprised
not to have enough food

cit.quote: Many people starved to death in the desert

sense.def: the way something or someone is at a specific time

sense.def: to give information clearly

cit.quote: Please state your name and address

sense.def: in a very un- happy, worried or upset condition

sense.def: in a dirty or bad condition

sense.def: some- thing that is spoken or written publicly

a place where trains stop and passengers get on or off

sense.def: a large main building for a service

sense.def: not moving
sense.note: NOTE: Do not confuse with stationery

sense.def: things such as paper, envelopes, pens and ink which you use for writing
sense.note: NOTE: no plural. Do not confuse with station- ary

sense.def: a solid image of a person or animal made from a substance such as stone or metal
social impor- tance when compared to other people

not to change

sense.def: regularly or continuously
firm and not moving or shaking

sense.def: contin- uing in a regular way

cit.quote: There is a steady demand for computers

cit.quote: He put out his hand to steady the ladder

sense.def: a thick piece of meat, usually beef

cit.quote: He ordered steak and chips
I'm going to grill these steaks

sense.def: a thick piece of a big fish

sense.def: to take and keep something that belongs to another per- son without permission

cit.quote: Someone tried to steal my handbag
He was ar- rested for stealing cars

sense.def: to move qui- etly

cit.quote: He stole into the cellar and tried to find the safe

sense.note: NOTE: Do not confuse with steel. Note also: steals -steal- ing -stole /stəυl/ -stolen / stəυlən/)

sense.def: the substance like clouds which comes off hot or boiling water

cit.quote: Clouds of steam were coming out of the kitchen

sense.def: a strong metal made from iron and carbon

cit.quote: Steel knives are best for the kitchen

sense.def: which rises or falls quickly

sense.def: very sharply increasing or falling

cit.quote: a steep increase in interest charges
a steep fall in share prices

sense.def: to make a vehicle go in a particular direction

cit.quote: She steered the car into the garage

sense.def: the tall thin part of a plant which holds a leaf, a flower or a fruit

sense.def: a movement of your foot when walking

entry.re: in step moving your feet at the same rate as everybody else ć I tried to keep in step with him as we walked along. ć The recruits can't even march in step
out of step moving your feet at a different rate from everyone else ć One of the squad always gets out of step
to take steps to to act to encourage or prevent something ć We should take steps to encourage female applicants. ć The museum must take steps to make sure that nothing else is stolen

sense.def: a machine which plays music or other sound through two different loudspeakers

cit.quote: I bought a new pair of speakers for my stereo

sense.def: serious and strict

sense.def: a dish of meat and veg- etables cooked together for a long time

sense.def: to cook food for a long time in liq- uid

cit.quote: Stew the apples until they are completely soft

sense.def: a thin branch of a tree
an- ything long and thin

cit.quote: carrots cut into sticks

sense.def: to attach something with glue

cit.quote: Can you stick the pieces of the cup together again?

They stuck a post- er on the door

sense.def: to be fixed or not to be able to move

sense.def: to push something into something

She stuck a needle into her finger

sense.def: to stay in a place

sense.def: to accept some- thing bad that continues

entry.re: to stick together to stay together ć If we stick together they should let us into the club
stick out phrasal verb 1. to push some- thing out 2. to be further forward or fur- ther away from something ć Your wallet is sticking out of your pocket. ć The balcony sticks out over the road

which does not move easily

sense.def: not moving

sense.def: continuing until now or until then

entry.re: find time / fand tam/ to do something even though you are busy ć In the middle of the meeting he still found time to phone his girl- friend. ć We must find time to visit the new staff sports club

entry.re: turn into phrasal verb 1. to change to become something different ć The witch turned the prince into a frog. ć We are planning to turn this room into a museum. 2. to change direction and go into something ć We went down the main road for a short way and then turned into a little lane on the left
turn round phrasal verb to move your head or body so that you face in another direction
turn back phrasal verb to turn round and go back in the opposite direction
turn down phrasal verb to refuse something which is offered ć She has turned down a job or turned a job down in the town hall

turn off phrasal verb 1. to make a piece of electrical equipment stop working ć Don't forget to turn the TV off when you go to bed. ć Turn off the lights or turn the lights off -father's going to show his holiday films. 2. to leave a road you are travelling on ć Here's where we turn off
turn on phrasal verb to make a piece of electrical equipment start working ć Can you turn the light on or turn on the light -it's too dark to read
turn over phrasal verb to roll over ć The lorry went round the corner too fast and turned over. ć Their boat turned over in the storm
turn up phrasal verb 1

form.pron: He doesn't know where the bottle is.

sense.def: used for referring to either of two things or people

sense.note: NOTE: Do not confuse with weather
